qas.question: Who were the first people to be called cardinals in Rome?

answers.text: the deacons of the seven regions of the city

qas.question: When were the Roman cardinals perceived as a privleged class among the Roman clergy?
What year did the ruling "only a cardinal was eligible to become pope" come in effect?
Who gave cardinals the right to elect the pope under the Papal Bull In nomine Domini?
What was it that gave cardinals the right to elect the pope?

answers.text: the Papal Bull In nomine Domini

qas.question: In what year did the pope allow cardinals to wear the red hats?
Who was the pope who gave cardinals the right to wear the hats?

plausible_answers.text: the deacons of the seven regions of the city

qas.question: Who were the first persons to be called cardinals at the beginning of the 7th century in Rome?
What did the word cardinal begin to mean at the beginning of the 8th century?
When were the Roman cardinals considered part of the peasant class?
In what year was the pope eligible to become a cardinal?
Who rescinded the right of the whole body of cardinals to elect the pope in 1179?

context: There is disagreement about the origin of the term, but general consensus that "cardinalis" from the word cardo (meaning 'pivot' or 'hinge') was first used in late antiquity to designate a bishop or priest who was incorporated into a church for which he had not originally been ordained. In Rome the first persons to be called cardinals were <a0_0><b7_0>the deacons of the seven regions of the city<b7_0/><a0_0/> at the beginning of the 6th century, when the word <b8_0>began to mean “principal,” “eminent,” or "superior."<b8_0/> The name was also given to the senior priest in each of the "title" churches (the parish churches) of Rome and to the bishops of the seven sees surrounding the city. By the <a1_0><b9_0>8th century<b9_0/><a1_0/> the Roman cardinals constituted a privileged class among the Roman clergy. They took part in the administration of the church of Rome and in the papal liturgy. By decree of a synod of <a2_0><b10_0>769<b10_0/><a2_0/>, only a cardinal was eligible to become pope. In 1059, during the pontificate of <a3_0>Nicholas II<a3_0/>, cardinals were given the right to elect the pope under <a4_0>the Papal Bull In nomine Domini<a4_0/>. For a time this power was assigned exclusively to the cardinal bishops, but the <b11_0>Third Lateran Council<b11_0/> in 1179 gave back the right to the whole body of cardinals. Cardinals were granted the privilege of wearing the red hat by <a6_0>Pope Innocent IV<a6_0/> in <a5_0>1244<a5_0/>.
